Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: REU Site: Polymer Innovation for a Sustainable Future
Award.AbstractNarration:
ID: 1359239 PI: Savin, Daniel ORG: University of Southern Mississippi

Title: SusChEM: REU Site: Polymer Innovation for a Sustainable Future

TECHNICAL PART: The research objective of the proposed REU site is to develop sustainable approaches to polymer materials development to meet critical societal needs. Undergraduate student researchers will be engaged in fundamental research projects that span the complex, interdisciplinary facets of materials sustainability, including polymer synthesis from renewable sources, materials with enhanced properties and lifetime, materials to improve utilization of natural resources, reduced energy polymer processes, and biodegradable materials, while gaining the tools to assess the environmental impact of new material development. The research is organized in four major thrusts: (1) Materials for the Preservation and Extension of Natural Resources, (2) Materials Designed for Zero Waste Using Biobased Raw Materials, (3) Materials Replacement for a Safer and more Secure Future, and (4) Improved Materials during Operating Conditions. The program includes a thorough training program for the graduate students who are selected as primary mentors of the REU participants.

NON-TECHNICAL PART: The program will recruit REU participants primarily from regional four-year and community colleges where opportunities for undergraduate research are scarce. Approximately 50% of the participants have been female during earlier funding periods for this REU, and approximately 30% were underrepresented minorities. Future recruiting will continue to promote broadening participation in the STEM enterprises. Housing and meals will be provided on campus for the participants, and funds have been allocated to support participants' travel to the Site. An expert evaluator will evaluate the program using instruments known to provide meaningful information about REU Site effectiveness, and the program will conduct systematic follow-up with program participants. Based on data from past REU experience, approximately 90% of participants subsequently enroll in graduate or professional study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU Site: Polymer Innovation for a Sustainable Future at the School of Polymer Science and Engineering at The University of Southern Mississippi engaged 32 undergraduate students from 29 institutions across the country in a ten-week program of summer research and training designed to equip them with the interdisciplinary research and teamwork skills necessary to address the complex challenges of the 21st century. Over the summers of 2014 – 2016, participants explored fundamental research that spanned the complex, interdisciplinary facets of materials sustainability, including polymer synthesis from renewable sources, materials with enhanced properties and lifetime, materials to improve utilization of natural resources, reduced energy polymer processes, and biodegradable materials.  Strengthening the theme of sustainability, students acquired skills and tools to assess the environmental impact of new material development, and were encouraged to consider these aspects at each stage of their research projects.  In addition to spending 40 hours per week in the laboratory with graduate students and faculty advisors, the diverse cohort of students (including 18 women and underrepresented minorities, and 19 from primarily undergraduate institutions) participated in foundational courses in polymer science and engineering, communication skills training, field trips to local industry, career exploration, and seminars by graduate students and visiting scientists.  The students practiced and developed effective scientific communication skills by providing two oral presentations and a final poster session explaining the results of their research.  REU participants worked on engaging the next generation of scientists and engineers by organizing an outreach event for 100 nine-eleven year olds participating in the local urban summer camp that featured hands-on activities sponsored by the NSF NISE-Net.  The research efforts of the participants resulted in three refereed publications and seventeen presentations at national and regional conferences with REU co-authors.  Twenty of the 32 participants are currently pursuing graduate degrees or applying to graduate school, eight have secured positions in industry, and the remaining students are still undergraduates in chemistry, biochemistry, engineering, or materials science at their home institutions. These results demonstrate the impact of the REU Site on building an educated workforce to address the grand challenges of science and engineering in our nation.
